title: Navigation drawer
description: Navigation drawers provide ergonomic access to destinations in an app.

contentChunks.htmlValue: There are two types of navigation drawers: standard and modal.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Standard navigation drawer
2. Modal navigation drawer
contentChunks.altText: 2 types of navigation drawers: standard and modal

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)
Available
M2 guideline – Navigation drawerAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposeAvailable
FlutterIn progress
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• Order destinations according to user importance, with frequent destinations first and related ones grouped together
  • Navigation drawers can be opened or closed by default to accommodate different app layouts
  • Standard navigation drawers are good for frequent switching to different destinations. Modal navigation drawers are good for infrequent, but more focused, switching.
What's new

• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color
  • Shape: Rounded corners on the ending edge of the drawer
  • States: Updated color and shape for indicating selected state

contentChunks.footer: Navigation drawer
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer illustrating color, shape, and selection

contentChunks.footer: M2: Navigation drawer had square corners and a rectangular shape indicating the active destination.
contentChunks.altText: M2 navigation drawer with 4 destinations in a mail app. The active destination “Inbox” is rectangular.

contentChunks.footer: M3: Navigation drawer has rounded corners, new color mappings, and an updated style for indicating the active destination.
contentChunks.altText: M3 navigation drawer with 4 destinations in a mail app. The active destination “Inbox” has rounded corners.

Color

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.

contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer with 4 primary destinations

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Navigation drawers provide access to destinations and app functionality, such as switching accounts. They can either be permanently on-screen or opened and closed by a navigation menu icon.

Navigation drawers are recommended for:

  • Apps with 5 or more top-level destinations
  • Apps with 2 or more levels of navigation hierarchy
  • Quick navigation between unrelated destinations
  • Replacing the navigation rail or navigation bar on large screens

contentChunks.footer: Use a navigation drawer for 5 or more primary destinations, or more than 1 level of navigation hierarchy
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer with multiple destinations in a mail app

contentChunks.footer: Avoid using a navigation drawer with other primary navigation components, such as a navigation bar. Instead, choose a single navigation component based on product requirements and device size: Navigation bars for small screens, navigation rails for tablet screens, and standard navigation drawers for desktop screens.
contentChunks.altText: Standard navigation drawer and navigation bar used together

contentChunks.htmlValue:
There are two types of navigation drawers:

  1. Standard navigation drawer
  2. Modal navigation drawer

contentChunks.footer: Standard navigation drawer
contentChunks.altText: Standard navigation drawer with destinations in mail app

contentChunks.footer: Modal navigation drawer
contentChunks.altText: Modal navigation drawer with destinations and scrim

contentChunks.htmlValue: Standard navigation drawer

Standard navigation drawers provide access to drawer destinations and app content on desktop and tablet screens. They’re often next to app content and affect the screen’s layout grid.

Standard drawers can be permanently visible (best for frequently switching destinations) or opened and closed by tapping a menu icon (best for focusing more on screen content).

On mobile screens, use modal drawers instead.

contentChunks.footer: Standard navigation drawer providing access to drawer destinations next to app content.
contentChunks.altText: Standard navigation drawer in a mail app with active destination “Inbox” next to app content

contentChunks.htmlValue: Modal navigation drawer

Modal navigation drawers use a scrim to block interaction with the rest of an app’s content, and don’t affect the screen’s layout grid.

Modal navigation drawers are primarily used on mobile screens where space is limited, or prioritized for app content.

They can be swapped with standard drawers on tablet and desktop.

contentChunks.footer: Modal navigation drawer using a scrim to block interaction with the rest of an app’s content.
contentChunks.altText: Modal navigation drawer with 1 active destination and scrim

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Modal navigation drawers are always opened by an action outside of the drawer, such as clicking a navigation menu icon in a navigation rail.

Modal drawers can be dismissed by:

  • Selecting a drawer item
  • Tapping the scrim
  • Swiping toward the drawer’s anchoring edge (for example,. swiping right-to-left for a left-aligned navigation drawer)

contentChunks.footer: A modal drawer opened by an action such as clicking a navigation menu icon (1).
contentChunks.altText: Diagram noting a navigation menu icon in a navigation rail

contentChunks.htmlValue: Modal drawers can be dismissed by tapping the scrim (1) or swiping the drawer toward its anchoring screen edge (2).

contentChunks.altText: 2 modal navigations illustrating tapping the scrim or swiping to dismiss a modal drawer

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy
Navigation drawers are essentially a list contained within a sheet. They can also include headers, subheads, and dividers to organize longer lists.

contentChunks.footer:
Navigation drawers can include headers, subheads, and dividers to organize longer lists.
1. Active Indicator
2. Icon
3. Label
4. Badge label
5. Sheet
6. Divider
7. Section label (optional)
8. Scrim
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer diagram numbering 8 elements

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Sheet

A sheet holds all navigation drawer elements. Side sheets are used as the container for standard and modal navigation drawers.

Navigation drawers that open from the side are always placed on the start edge of the screen, on the left for left-to-right languages, and on the right for right-to-left languages.

contentChunks.footer: A navigation drawer opens from the left side of the screen for left-to-right languages.
contentChunks.altText: Modal navigation drawer opening from left side of screen

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Header (optional)

The header area of a navigation drawer is a flexible space that can be used for brand expression (such as an app title or logo), an account switcher, and more.

contentChunks.footer: If branding is a priority, a branding element can be placed in the header area of a navigation drawer.
contentChunks.altText: Modal navigation drawer with branding element in header area

contentChunks.footer: If a navigation drawer is the full vertical height of the page, a branding element or product name can be placed in the header area.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer with branding element in header area

contentChunks.footer: If a navigation drawer is clipped by a top app bar, don’t place a branding element or product name in the header. In this case, the top app bar is a more suitable place for that content.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer clipped by top app bar

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Divider (optional)

Dividers can be used to separate groups of destinations within the navigation drawer.

contentChunks.footer: Use full-width dividers (1) to separate groups of destinations.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer using horizontal dividers to separate a group of destinations

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use dividers to separate individual destinations.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer using horizontal dividers to separate individual destinations

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Active indicator

The active indicator is a background shape communicating which destination of the navigation drawer is currently being displayed.

contentChunks.footer: The active indicator (1) is a background shape communicating which destination of the navigation drawer is currently being displayed.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer diagram numbering 1 element

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Label text and icons

Destinations in a navigation drawer take the form of actionable list items. Each item describes its destination using label text and an optional icon.

contentChunks.footer: Actionable list items in a navigation drawer describe each destination using an option icon (1) and label text (2).
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer diagram numbering 2 elements

contentChunks.htmlValue: Label text should be clear and short enough that it isn’t cut off by the sheet.

contentChunks.footer: Navigation drawers can use text labels without icons.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer using only label text for 4 destinations. Label text “Inbox” in active destination

contentChunks.footer: Keep text labels concise, but truncate them if they extend beyond the container width.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer with 1 truncated text label

contentChunks.footer: Don’t wrap label text.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer with 1 text label with wrapped label text

contentChunks.footer: Don’t shrink text size in order to fit a text label on a single line.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer with 1 text label featuring smaller text

contentChunks.htmlValue: Icons can supplement labels as indicators of a destination. When used, they should always be placed before text. Other app components and content should reference these icons.

contentChunks.footer: Use recognizable icons when conventions exist.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer with active destination “Inbox” featuring recognizable icon

contentChunks.footer: Don’t apply icons to some destinations and not others. Icons should be used for all destinations, or none.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer with 4 destinations, 2 with text label and icon, 2 with only text label

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Section label (optional)

Short subhead section labels can help group related destinations in the navigation drawer.

contentChunks.footer: Related destinations can be grouped using short subhead section labels in the navigation drawer
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer showing subhead section labels

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Scrim (modal only)

Modal navigation drawers use a scrim to block interaction with the rest of the app. The scrim is placed directly behind the drawer’s sheet and can be tapped or clicked to dismiss the drawer.

contentChunks.footer: Scrim applied behind a modal navigation drawer.
contentChunks.altText: Modal navigation drawer with scrim placed behind

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Responsive layout

Learn more about responsive layouts and break points.

A product’s navigation component should change to suit the size and form factor of the screen.

Standard navigation drawers are best for screens at large breakpoints of 1240dp or greater. At tablet breakpoints, swap out the navigation drawer for a navigation rail. At mobile breakpoints, swap the rail for a navigation bar.

contentChunks.footer: Standard navigation drawers change size to suit the device’s screen.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail changing to navigation drawer on a larger screen

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Mobile

Use modal navigation drawers on screens with breakpoints between 360dp and 599dp.

For small devices, horizontal space is at a premium and the body area of an app usually spans the entire width of a screen.

contentChunks.footer: Use a modal navigation drawer on mobile screens.
contentChunks.altText: Modal navigation drawer with 1 active destination

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Tablet

On medium-sized devices like tablets, make the standard navigation drawer collapsible or swap the drawer for a navigation rail.

contentChunks.footer: Use a persistent standard navigation drawer on tablet screens, or allow the drawer to open and close via a menu icon.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer on tablet with 1 active destination

contentChunks.htmlValue: On devices with 1240dp+ widths, present destinations in a permanently visible or dismissible navigation drawer.

contentChunks.footer: Use a standard navigation drawer on large and desktop screens.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer showing 1 active destination

contentChunks.htmlValue:
When a navigation rail and modal navigation drawer are used together, the modal drawer can repeat destinations in the navigation rail as long as the drawer offers enough visual separation between levels of the navigation hierarchy.

Use a transition to signal the switch of an on-screen component. For example, when shifting from portrait to landscape orientations, the navigation rail should transform into a navigation drawer.

contentChunks.footer: The modal navigation drawer can repeat destinations from the navigation rail.
contentChunks.altText: Side-by-side navigation rail and navigation drawer with the same destinations

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

Scrolling

Navigation drawers can be vertically scrolled, independent of the rest of the screen’s content and UI. If the list of navigation destinations is longer than the height of the drawer, the drawer’s contents can be scrolled within the drawer.

contentChunks.footer: Scrolling vertically allows navigation drawers to move independently from the rest of the screen.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation drawer scrolled vertically, with contents within the drawer scrolled independently

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Visibility

Dismissible standard drawers can be used for layouts that prioritize content (such as a photo gallery) or for apps where users are unlikely to switch destinations often. They should use a visible navigation menu icon to open and close the drawer.

contentChunks.footer: A standard dismissible navigation drawer is opened and closed by tapping the navigation menu icon in the top app bar (1), and remains open until the menu icon is tapped again (2).
contentChunks.altText: Side-by-side standard navigation drawer opened and then closed after tapping menu bar

contentChunks.htmlValue: Permanently visible standard drawers allow quick navigation between unrelated destinations. They can’t be closed or dismissed by the user.

contentChunks.footer: A permanently visible standard navigation drawer on desktop.
contentChunks.altText: Standard navigation drawer moving between destinations

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Accessibility guidelines coming soon

In progress: complete guidance for accessible interaction, keyboard navigation, labeling, and more. Learn more about accessibility.
